faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.q1: What is Search Console for iOS?
faq.a1: Search Console for iOS is a native iPhone and iPad app that connects to Google Search Console via the official API. It lets you monitor your website's search performance, view clicks, impressions, CTR, average position, analyze search queries, check Core Web Vitals, and more - all from your mobile device.
faq.q2: Is there an official Google Search Console app?
faq.a2: No, Google does not offer an official Search Console app for iPhone. Search Console for iOS is an independent third-party app that uses Google's official Search Console API to bring your search data to your iPhone and iPad.
faq.q3: How do I access Google Search Console on iPhone?
faq.a3: Download Search Console for iOS from the App Store and sign in with your Google account. The app uses secure OAuth authentication to connect to your Search Console properties. You can also use Safari to visit search.google.com/search-console, but a native app provides a much better mobile experience.
faq.q4: What features does the app include?
faq.a4: The app includes performance analytics (clicks, impressions, CTR, average position), search query analysis, top pages monitoring, Core Web Vitals (LCP, CLS, INP), URL inspection, sitemap management, device and country filtering, custom date ranges, interactive charts, and push notifications for performance alerts.
faq.a5: Tap "Sign in with Google" and use the same Google account that has access to your Search Console properties. The app uses OAuth for secure authentication - your password is never stored or accessed by the app.
faq.a6: Yes. The app connects directly to Google's official Search Console API using OAuth 2.0. Your data stays in your Google account - I don't store, collect, or have access to your Search Console data. All data shown is based on what Google collects and what you have enabled in your Google Account settings. You can manage your Google privacy settings here.
faq.privacyLinkText: manage your Google privacy settings here
faq.q7: Is this app affiliated with Google?
faq.a7: No. Search Console for iOS is an independent third-party app. It is not made by, affiliated with, endorsed by, or sponsored by Google LLC. The app uses Google's publicly available Search Console API.
faq.a8: Yes, you can cancel anytime through iPhone Settings > your name > Subscriptions. You'll keep access until the end of your current billing period.
faq.q9: Why is the app not free?
faq.a9: The subscription covers continued app development and API costs. Unlike free apps that rely on ads or selling user data, Search Console for iOS has no ads and never accesses your data. Your subscription directly supports ongoing updates, new features, and improvements. Try it free for 7 days before subscribing.
faq.q10: Why can't I see my website?
faq.a10: Make sure your website is verified in Google Search Console on the web first. The app only shows properties you have access to in your Google account. If you recently added a site, try signing out and back in to refresh your properties.
faq.q11: Does the app work on iPad?
faq.a11: Yes. Search Console for iOS works on both iPhone and iPad running iOS 18.0 or later. The interface adapts to take advantage of larger iPad screens.
faq.q12: Can I view Core Web Vitals?
faq.a12: Yes. The app displays your Core Web Vitals including Largest Contentful Paint (LCP), Cumulative Layout Shift (CLS), and Interaction to Next Paint (INP) for both mobile and desktop.
faq.a13: Yes. All websites you have access to in Google Search Console will appear in the app. You can easily switch between them from the main screen.
faq.q14: How often is the data updated?
faq.a14: Data is fetched directly from Google's Search Console API each time you open the app or pull to refresh. Note that Google's Search Console data typically has a 2-3 day processing delay - this is a Google limitation, not an app limitation.
faq.q15: What date ranges can I view?
faq.a15: You can view data for the last 24 hours, 7 days, 28 days, 3 months, 6 months, 12 months, or 16 months - matching the options available in Google Search Console.
faq.a16: Not yet. I'm focused on iOS first. Sign up for updates and I'll let you know if an Android version is planned.
faq.a17: The app caches your most recent data, so you can view it offline. However, an internet connection is required to fetch new data from Google.

about.metaDescription: The story behind Search Console for iOS. Why I built this app and what drives its development.
about.heroTitle:
Built by someone
who needed it
about.heroSubtitle: The story behind Search Console for iOS
about.authorBio: I built this app because I needed it myself. No big company, no VC funding - just one developer solving a problem I face every day.
about.storyP1: I use Search Console to keep tabs on my website, but honestly? The mobile experience is rough. I got tired of jumping into Safari every time I wanted to check something quick.
about.storyP2: I saw Google has an API for it, and based on all the forum posts I've read, it doesn't seem like they're planning to build an app anytime soon. The options on the App Store didn't really do it for me either. One looked sketchy, the others just felt off.
about.storyHighlight: "There has to be a better way to check my search data on the go."
about.storyP4: It does what I need. I can check my keywords, see which pages are getting traffic, and keep an eye on Core Web Vitals. Nothing fancy, just the stuff I actually want to see when I open the app.
about.storyP5: I'm not a big company. It's just me, building something I use every day. If you've felt the same frustration, maybe it'll work for you too.
about.valuePrivacyDesc: Your data stays in your Google account. The app displays what Google collects - I don't store or sell anything. Manage your Google privacy.
about.valueFastDesc: No bloat. Open the app, see your data. Built for quick checks on the go.
about.valueImprovingDesc: Your subscription supports active development. New features ship regularly.
about.ctaSubtitle: Download Search Console for iOS from the App Store.

releases.metaTitle: Release History - Search Console for iOS
releases.metaDescription: Track the evolution of Search Console for iOS. See all releases, features, and improvements in a visual timeline.
releases.heroDesc: Track the evolution of Search Console for iOS. Every update brings new features, improvements, and refinements.
releases.v105Fix1: Fixed crash when switching result type to Discover or Google News
releases.v105Fix2: No-data alert now uses system pop-up; result type reverts to last working selection
releases.v105Feat1: Multi-language support: German, French, Japanese, Korean, Portuguese, Simplified and Traditional Chinese
releases.v105Feat2: Full UI localization: settings, about, charts, Core Web Vitals, notifications, achievements
releases.v105Imp1: Chart: localized axis labels and compact metric cards for all languages
releases.v105Imp2: Removed Last 24 hours date range: chart now uses reliable daily data only (API does not provide hourly data)
releases.v105Note: If you selected Discover or Google News and saw no data, the app now shows a simple alert and switches the dropdown back to your last working view.
releases.v104_1: Minor bug fixes and stability improvements
releases.v103Fix1: Fixed subscription screen not loading when starting a free trial or subscribing
releases.v103Fix2: Clearer error messages and retry when a subscription or restore fails
releases.v103Imp1: Improved theming for light and dark mode across the app
releases.v103Imp2: Version and build number now shown consistently in About
releases.v103Note: If you had trouble starting a subscription or restoring a purchase, this update fixes that. Thank you for your patience.
releases.v102_1: Improved subscription loading and error handling
releases.v101_1: Settings: Added search bar to find options quickly
releases.v101_2: Settings: Default Insights date range and Home Quick Actions customization
releases.v101_3: Settings: Open Notification Settings and Rate App in About
releases.v101_4: About: Patch Notes section with high-level updates and bug fixes
releases.v101_5: About: Version row now shows build number
releases.v100_1: Performance analytics with date range and chart view
releases.v100_2: Search Queries and Top Pages with filters and export
releases.v100_3: Core Web Vitals (LCP, CLS, INP) with mobile and desktop
releases.v100_5: Insights home with quick actions and customizable tiles
releases.v100_6: Daily, weekly, and monthly report notifications
releases.v100_10: Memory and async leak fixes for stable usage
releases.v100_11: 24-hour chart: hourly interpolation and projected data

guide.metaTitle: How to Use Google Search Console on iPhone | Step-by-Step Guide
guide.metaDescription: Learn how to check your website's performance, ranking, and SEO data on iPhone using Google Search Console. Complete guide for 2026.
guide.title: How to Use Google Search Console on iPhone
guide.intro: Checking your website's SEO performance on the go shouldn't be hard. This guide explains how to access Google Search Console data directly from your iPhone.
guide.whyTitle: Why Monitor Search Console on Mobile?
guide.whyBody: Website issues can happen anytime. Being able to check your critical metrics - like organic traffic drops or indexing errors - from your phone allows you to react faster. Whether you are an SEO professional, a developer, or a business owner, having access to your search data in your pocket is a game-changer.
guide.method1Body: Google does not provide an official iOS app for Search Console. However, third-party apps like Search Console for iOS fill this gap by using Google's official API to provide a secure and optimized mobile experience.
guide.benefit1: Native Charts: Smooth, interactive charts optimized for touch screens.
guide.benefit2: Push Notifications: Get alerted daily or weekly about your site's performance.
guide.benefit3: Widgets: View key metrics right on your home screen.
guide.benefit4: Multiple Accounts: Easily switch between different Google accounts and properties.
guide.method2Body: You can also access the web version of Google Search Console via Safari or Chrome on your iPhone.
guide.method2Step3: Sign in with your Google account.
guide.method2Note: While this works, the web interface is designed for desktop monitors. Charts may be hard to read, and navigating complex reports on a small screen can be frustrating.
guide.metricsIntro: When checking from your phone, focus on high-level health metrics:
guide.metric1: Total Clicks & Impressions: Is your traffic stable?
guide.metric2: Average Position: Are your key rankings holding steady?
guide.metric3: Core Web Vitals: Is your site passing mobile usability tests?
